ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to think critically about research in the field of Psychology and communicate my thoughts in a concise manner.
This class taught me a lot about irrationality, and why we think the way we do. One of the best skills I learned from this course was how to apply concepts we learned in the classroom to real life.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of this course are the captivating and caring professor, fascinating and applicable content, and a diverse group of students contributing to our weekly discussions.

The (very) small seminar format was a huge plus for me - everyone was unmuted all the time, we could interrupt, ask questions, laugh, make comments. Although the sessions are quite long (almost 2 hours on most days), time moved faster than slower. When in discussion with peers, it always seemed like we didn't have enough time. Also because the group was so small, we became very close, and we were able to open up, share, and connect in a deeper way than I experienced in other classes/sections. Professor Ahn is wonderful and she cares a lot about her students. She is always more than happy to help if you ask nicely. Her powerpoints are also the creme de la creme.

Weaknesses: sometimes time did pass slowly if you didn't fully engage, so be sure to do the readings and pay attention.
The best course I have ever taken, no weaknesses at all
I would have liked if the class was more challenging and less surface level or obvious feeling

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A break during the Zoom seminar.
The class was very interesting, but also very long. It would have helped to have a short break in the middle, so we could return energized.
All "virtual" aspects of this course was great: small seminar "unmuted" style, sharing powerpoints on screen, uploading lecture slides and videos after class
the course was well structured and it all worked smothly

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Of course I would! It was my favorite course this entire semester due to the strengths I listed above (great professor, interesting content, wonderful peers).
Yes! Take it!!!! Super interesting, and don't let the "senior seminar" label intimidate you (it seemed to hold no relevancy at all besides your option for the final paper).

I would absolutely recommend this course as a seminar! The best course I have ever taken at Yale and professor Ahn is absolutely fantastic and makes the class extremely interesting. You learn so much cool things in this class!
